instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 1.39v
threads.message:
Working on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board with no backlight, and the sleep light stays on; I checked <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>, and it's 1.39v. BIL area looks fine, as does area for <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R6961</RESISTOR>. Both resistors measure fine. SMC area looks fine, but this board actually had a pretty major burn near <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR>, which I repaired, so I wonder if the surge that caused that damage also zapped the SMC. Board powers up and works fine, but the front sleep light stays on and backlight stays off.

Would the next course of action be to replace the SMC? I don't see anything that would affect <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>. Diode mode on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is .687, so doesn't appear shorted or anything, just low. 

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 1.39v
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR> ok?  

Typically it's either <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR>, crap under the SMC, or a burn in the firewire area. <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> makes its way to the SMC through the firewire area, so a hole or serious corrosion in that area will short it to ground around 40-200 ohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 1.39v
threads.message: Board is entirely clean except near <TRANSISTOR>Q7055</TRANSISTOR> where I repaired some burning. Checked everything there, nothing close to BIL or anywhere near <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>, of course. No damage or burning near firewire. <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR> measures fine (100k); I have ~1.5v at <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR> pin 1 (<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>) and 3.42v on pin 2 (pp3v42). Replaced <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR> to be sure, and same issues. This is looking more and more like an SMC issue, yes? With 3v42 on pin 2 to pull up <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>, and it still only at ~1.5v, then that would mean the SMC isn't spitting it out properly, I'd assume?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 1.39v
threads.message: Also, I ran a small wire from pin 1 to pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR>, and backlight works (but no sleep when lid is closed, of course), so the issue is definitely that <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is missing/low. I figured that was the cause of no backlight, but did want to include that bit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 1.39v
threads.message: Did you removed BIL?? other than that it is a bad SMC for me......

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 1.39v
threads.message: Thanks, Aprendiz. I haven't removed BIL, since that area looks perfectly fine, but will do so. If that doesn't work, I'll proceed to replace SMC. Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 1.39v
threads.message: Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>, should be higher than 100K of course. Any component with a GND connection on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> can cause this and it could even be the board itself.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 1.39v
threads.message:
Thanks, Duke. I replaced the SMC, no change. Not sure what the issue is, but I'm getting close to calling it an internal partial shorting of <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL>.

I did have one more piece of information that may be relevant; the measurement for <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> bounces around quite a lot; from 1.27v to 1.39v, as high as 1.5v, back down to 1.10v, then back up; never reaches more than right around 1.5v and never drops lower than ~1.17v. I didn't realize how unsteady it was until watching it for a few seconds. 

Going to toss this one into the parts pile unless there's some work-around.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> 1.39v
threads.message: Removed <RESISTOR>R6961</RESISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q5701</TRANSISTOR> to rule out anything else besides the PCB itself? With those removed if the problem persists it will be the PCB. Still sort of fixable to decrease the pull up resistor value, but the PCB may degrade further of course.
